Getting Past No by William Ury



1. Get Ready

"Diplomacy is the art of letting someone else have your way." - Daniele Vare

Take a "joint problem-solving" approach. Focus on the problem not the people. Instead of attacking each other, jointly attack the problem.

5 Barriers to Cooperation:

  1. Your Reaction
    1. The first barrier lies within you.
    2. Don't just strike back to strike back, but don't give in either.
    3. Suspend your reaction.
    4. "Go to the "Balcony".
  2. Their Emotion
    1. Try seeing things for their point of view.
  3. Their position
    1. What are their real interests
    2. Every man has two reasons for doing a thing -- the one he says, and the real one.
    3. Say "tell me more" and "how do you mean"
    4. Reframe
  4. Their Dissatisfaction
    1. Build a golden bridge
    2. Help them save face and make the outcome look as good for them as possible.
  5. Their Power
    1. Don't use power to escalate, but to educate

The great home run hitter Sadahara Oh, the Japanese Babe Ruth, looked at every opposing pitcher as his partner, with every pitch as an opportunity.

Treat your opponent as a negotiating partner.

Rather than telling them what to do, you let them figure it out. Your job is to help them.

"Before every meeting, prepare. After every meeting, assess your progress, adapt your strategy, and prepare again."

Mapping a way to agreement:

  1. Interests
    1. Figure out your interests.
    2. Figure out their interests.
  2. Options
    1. Don't just divvy up the pie, make the pie bigger
    2. A classic mistake is to focus on a single solution, you need options
  3. Standards
    1. Rely heavily on fair, independent standards
    2. Market value, the law, or usual practices can be such standards
  4. Alternatives
    1. BATNA = Best Alternative to a Negotiated Agreement
    2. Your BATNA is your walkaway alternative. The ability to walkaway.
    3. BATNA is the key to negotiating power.
    4. Identify and boost your BATNA
    5. Identify their BATNA
    6. Figure out a solution that is better than BOTH sides' BATNA

Break Through Strategies:

1. Don't React: Go to the Balcony

"Speak when you are angry and you will make the best speech you will ever regret." - Ambrose Bierce

The natural reactions: striking back, giving in, breaking off

Remember, for every action, there is an equal and opposite reaction

The "balcony" is a metaphor for a mental attitude of detachment.

Imagine yourself on the stage, then imagine yourself on the balcony overlooking the state.

Name the Game:

  1. Stone Walls
    1. Ex: "I can't do anything about it."
    2. A good tactic is to ignore it
  2. Attacks
    1. Ex: "Do it or else!"
    2. Ignore it, or make a joke about
    3. Don't take it personally
  3. Tricks
    1. Expose them

"We live and work in competitive environments. So expect verbal attacks and don't take them personally."

Accusers are trying to get a reaction out of you. Deny them that.

Once you have named the gamed (See above) go out to the balcony.

Take a time out. Make an excuse for a short break. Just get out of the room for second.

"Never make an important decision on the spot. Go to the balcony and make it there."

Don't get mad, Don't get even, Get what you want


2. Don't Argue: Step to Their Side

You can't reason with a person who is not receptive.

The secret of disarming is surprise.

Listen actively. Hear the other side out.

When they are done talking. Encourage them to keep talking. Real reasons may emerge at the very end.

"Effective negotiators listen far more than they talk."

Paraphrase what they are saying and acknowledge their points.

Agree, without conceding, wherever you can.

Accumulate Yeses. The key word in agreement is "yes."

Acknowledge the person and distinguish between the person and the behavior.

Express your views without provoking. Instead of either/or, use both/and

Don't say "But," say "Yes... And"
NEVER say "but". SAY "and". Customer says prices are too high. You say, "and our quality is too high."


3. Don't Reject: Reframe

Reframing is talking about the problem. Focus on the problem, not the people involved.

Ask problem solving questions. "Why?" "Why not?" "What if?"

Ask for their advice.

Ask "What makes that fair?"

Don't ask leading questions. Make your questions open-ended.


4. Don't Push: Build Them A Golden Bridge

"Build your opponent a golden bridge to retreat across." - Sun Tzu

Obstacles to Agreement:

  1. Not their idea
  2. Unmet interests
  3. Fear of losing face
  4. Too much too fast

Always help them save face.

They should be able to go back home and have people think they did well.


5. Don't Escalate: Use Power to Educate

"The best general is the one who never fights." - Sun Tzu

The power paradox: the harder you make it for them to say no, the harder you make it for them to say yes

Use power to bring them to their senses, not to their knees

Let them know the consequences.

Ask reality-testing questions:

Demonstrate your BATNA

Warn, don't threaten

Use the minimum power necessary, use legitimate means

Tap the third force: build a coalition and bring in third parties on your side


Finally: From Adversaries to Partners

"Do I not destroy my enemies when I make them my friends?" - Lincoln
